body:
> Naming. Why is one named with the angle unit, and not the other?

I agree `angleDeg` would have been a better name although, from my experience, I don't think deprecating `angle` just for this reason would get enough support considering libGDX history on how it deals with backwards compatibility and deprectation PRs. Feel free to submit a PR though.

> Result range. Why is one always positive, and not the other?

I don't see an issue that "degrees methods" return in the range between `[0, 360]` and "radians methods" between `[-Math.Pi, Math.Pi]` because either you work with one or the other (and if you need converting it's trivial). It's simply a convention, it's common to use the `[-Math.Pi, Math.Pi]` range when working with polar coordinates.
What I agree is that consistency should be required for all methods with the same unit, so, ALL degrees methods should return in the `[0, 360]` range and ALL radians methods in the `[-Math.Pi, Math.Pi]`. Currently this is not the case (`Vector2.angle` and `Vector2.angle(Vector2 reference)` return in different ranges).

>Currently this is not the case (Vector2.angle and Vector2.angle(Vector2 reference) return in different ranges)

This is indeed way much worse. It advocate the need to unify the ranges of result for angle functions.

> I don't think deprecating angle just for this reason

Naming is a secondary reason. Range of return value is important. Theses inconsistencies in result ranges makes the usage of angle functions error-prone.

> (and if you need converting it's trivial)

It would be even more trivial if the ranges were consistent. Currently conversion needs to use one conditions, which means 2 execution paths. If the ranges were consistent, conversion would not need any condition and would have only 1 execution path.

>I don't see an issue that "degrees methods" return in the range between [0, 360] and "radians methods" between [-Math.Pi, Math.Pi]

I don't see why they should have different result range. Having different result ranges, only hurts consistency, and least astonishment principle.

>It's simply a convention, it's common to use the [-Math.Pi, Math.Pi] range when working with polar coordinates.

Yes. I haven't propose to change `angleRad` for that reason. But this convention is true regardless of the unit used. This is no excuse for having `angle` returning angles between `[0, 360]`.

>Yes. I haven't propose to change angleRad for that reason. But this convention is true regardless of the unit used. This is no excuse for having angle returning angles between [0, 360].

No, that convention is not true regardless of the unit used. The convention for degrees is [0, 360] and we must keep it like that.

>No, that convention is not true regardless of the unit used. The convention for degrees is [0, 360]

Can you please share the source of this statement?

I don't read anything like that here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sign_(mathematics), nor here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_angles.

Other game engines also use angles between `[-180, 180]` for degrees:
* https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Vector2.Angle.html
* https://api.unrealengine.com/INT/API/Runtime/Core/Math/FVector/UnwindEuler/index.html

[Geographic coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system) are also a good example of angle in degrees between `[-180, 180]` (for longitude) and between `[-90, 90]` (for the latitude).

In the 2D world and the non engineering specialised world everybody is used to work in the [0º,360º] range and this is how it works across most libGDX classes ranging from Math utils classes, to Camera, etc... The word `convention` means that is what people usually use, nothing else, you won't find a statement online, just ask anybody how they usually work in 2D geometry.

I don't know about 3D engines Unity and Unreal but those 2 links you provide don't proof all the functions on the engine work on that range (here's for example a link to a class that works on the [0,360] https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Transform-eulerAngles.html). Even if they did though, it doesn't matter, we can do better/simpler because Vector2 is 2D only.

> The word convention means that is what people usually use, nothing else, you won't find a statement online, just ask anybody how they usually work in 2D geometry.

So please, share the source stating that users usually use ranges between `[0, 360]` for angles in degrees.

Usually traces of well established conventions can be found in books or online. If no source of a "convention" can be found, then it is not a very good spread convention but more a personal preference.

Here's some random sources of conventions:
* Java conventions: https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/codeconventions-150003.pdf
* Kotlin code-style conventions: https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/coding-conventions.html
* Vector representation conventions: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_vector?section=8#Representations
* Sign conventions in math: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sign_(mathematics)#Sign_convention
* Human names conventions: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_name#Naming_conventions

I could continue this endless list, but that's not the point. The point is : "Well established conventions have written sources"

And about "just ask anybody how they usually work in 2D geometry": I studied 4 years and worked full-time 2 years in the domain of 2D geometry. I'm not able to remember such convention. This is also why I am astonished by your statement, and therefore ask you to source it.

>those 2 links you provide don't proof all the functions on the engine work on that range 

Indeed they don't. But (I think) it is a good clue that the "convention" you mentioned either doesn't exist or is not that strong. Otherwise it would have been harder to find examples in such popular frameworks. But I know this is no proof. That's why I asked you to source your statement, which is the only way to *prove* the existence of such convention.

Be also aware that I found theses links by genuinely looking for confirmation of your statement. I thought that this convention could be confined to the video-game world, which would have explained my misunderstanding of the subject. But it doesn't seem to be the case. Or at least I haven't found a good source of it.

And also notice that my example with unity, was the exact equivalent of the function we are currently talking about. It was not an exotic documentation talking about something else. (my example with UE4 was not the exact equivalent, because I failed to find the equivalent. If you find it, please share it)

Please read the documentation you shared for unity as well. It talk about input, not output and doesn't mention the range. Only that it'll fail if the input angles are greater than 360°. Nothing says we cannot use negatives angles (maybe we can, maybe we cannot, I don't know).

If both `[-180, +180]` and `[0, 360]` are possible, I think, `[-180, +180]` should be favored in order to have a better consistency with the other functions.

Wow. There was no need for all that, I've clearly defined what I meant by `convention` but you seem just to have ignored it.

Anyway, feel free to provide a PR, I think I've made my point.

>I've clearly defined what I meant by convention but you seem just to have ignored it.

It seems I've not understood your point then. Can you please point out what I have "ignored"?

All `Vector` methods dealing with angles in degrees use plain names, those in radians have `Rad` suffix. That seems pretty consistent and beginner friendly, so I see no need to change that.

Similarly, using 0-360 seems like a more beginner friendly way to represent angles, it is well documented and user code may rely on it.

I frankly don't see any issue here. From what I have seen and experienced, projects use either degrees or radians, without hardly any mixing of the two, so having two separate "conventions" doesn't seem like a big deal, especially considering that most functions don't care whether they get -10 or 350 deg, and angles are separately normalized if they do.

I aggree it is not a "big deal". I'm only saying it can be better.

However, we probably not have the same definition of "beginner friendly". I find it very difficult for a beginner to understand why none of `angle()`, `angle(Vector2)`, `angle()` and `angleRad(Vector2)` behave consistently. It would be so much simpler to get started if theses functions would be consistent.

The current behavior is:
* `angle()` returns between `[0, 360]` toward `+y`
* `angle(Vector2)` returns between `[-180, 180]` toward `-y`
* `angleRad()` returns between `[-Math.PI, Math.PI]` toward `+y`
* `angleRad(Vector2)` returns between `[-Math.PI, Math.PI]` toward `-y`

Do you really find that "beginner friendly"?

My conception of "beginner friendly" would be more:
* `angle()` returns between `[-180, 180]` toward `+y`
* `angle(Vector2)` returns between `[-180, 180]` toward `+y`
* `angleRad()` returns between `[-Math.PI, Math.PI]` toward `+y`
* `angleRad(Vector2)` returns between `[-Math.PI, Math.PI]` toward `+y`

>user code may rely on it.

That's why I don't propose to change it, but to deprecate it and provide an alternative.

I wonder how can one argue that the `angle()` function doesn't fall into the "black sheep" code smell.

Let me state it once again: `angle()` is the **only** angle function (out of 4) which doesn't return values between `[-halfCircle, +halfCircle]`.

> I wonder how can one argue that the `angle()` function doesn't fall into the "black sheep" code smell.
> 
> Let me state it once again: `angle()` is the **only** angle function (out of 4) which doesn't return values between `[-halfCircle, +halfCircle]`.

Nobody has. 

This inconsistency was actually detected by me on my first reply before you edited your post to add it.

>What I agree is that consistency should be required for all methods with the same unit, so, ALL degrees methods should return in the [0, 360] range and ALL radians methods in the [-Math.Pi, Math.Pi]. Currently this is not the case (Vector2.angle and Vector2.angle(Vector2 reference) return in different ranges).

I'll create a PR for it (waitig for some fixes to be merged as libGDX project doesn't currently build).

So please, stop editing your posts and comments hours after reponses have been made, otherwise the discussion doesn't make any sense.

Thanks @obigu.

Sorry, I only update my initial request in order to make it clearer, since it was apparently not clear enough.

But the reasons of my proposal as well as the proposal itself hasn't changed.


*EDIT:*
>*This inconsistency was actually detected by me on my first reply before you edited your post to add it.*

*And thank you for pointing that inconsistency. But how the fact that I added this inconsistency in my initial post for more clarity change anything? Does it make the inconsistency not present anymore?*

Hi guys.

Just to sum it up - we all agree that there are inconsistent APIs behaviour.

So there are 2 approaches that are discussed here:
1. In next version - deprecate old APIs and introduce newer ones
    a. In next version + 1 - remove the deprecated APIs
    b. (optional) in next version + 2 - rename the new APIs to the old APIs naming
2. Change the behavior of the inconsistent API

I find first approach more constructive and more appealing as per backward compatibility aspects for the consumers of the inconsistent API.
First approach will clearly state in compile time what and how to adapt (given all Javadoc is in place), whether the second approach will just break the consumer.
Wdyt?

**EDIT:**
On another note, point 1b might be problematic for consumers that upgrading from this version or lower to the next version +2 - they will fall into the same trap of a hidden breaking change, if they don't read the release notes of each version and version carefully.

issue.title: Fix #5388. Made Vector2 angle methods consistent
issue.body:
Fix #5388 and #5385.

This PR contains two different changes to Vector2 angle methods:
1. Fixed `angle(Vector2)` and `angleRad(Vector2)` to return counter-clockwise angles as specified in their javadocs.
2. Made `angle(Vector2)` consistent to `angle()` to return values in the [0, 360) range.
